newsitem.title: USA: Rubin reiterates support for strong dollar.
newsitem.headline: Rubin reiterates support for strong dollar.

text.p: U.S. Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin Thursday reiterated his support for a strong dollar, saying it was in the U.S. interest.
"Our policy remains the same. A strong dollar is in our economic interests," he told reporters, adding, "The dollar is not to be used as an instrument of trade policy."

The financial markets have been rife with speculation about a shift in U.S. dollar policy after senior Japanese official Eisuke Sakakibara told a newspaper last week that the dollar's rise against the yen was about to come to an end.

That speculation was fanned on Thursday by a newspaper report that influential private economist Fred Bergsten is being considered for a top post in President Clinton's second administration. Bergsten has in the past called for a weaker dollar to help cut the big U.S. trade deficit.
Rubin declined to comment on the Bergsten report. "There are all kinds of names being bandied about," he said. "I don't think I should comment on individuals."
He also declined comment on whether he would stay on as Treasury chief in a second Clinton term. However, sources close to the Secretary confirmed that he would.
Rubin's comments on the dollar came in the wake of a series of remarks by Japanese and European officials Thursday that seemed designed to talk the U.S. currency back up.

Asked if the barrage of comments were a coordinated effort to buttress the dollar after Sakakibara's remarks knocked it lower last week, Rubin said, "I can't speak to the rest of them ... As far as I know, at least, we haven't been coordinating with anybody about anything."
Sakakibara also said last week that he thought the financial markets were taking an overly pessimistic view about the Japanese economy.
Rubin declined comment on that, although he did reiterate America's "very strong interest" in a strong Japanese economy led by domestic demand.
The Treasury chief made his remarks on the dollar in response to questions at the end of a briefing on next week's meeting here between U.S. and Chinese economic policymakers.
